posts.name: Ryan
posts.cooked:
Our team doesn’t usually color our robot but for future seasons we were looking into more options. It looks like it’s relatively simple to anodize aluminum with things we have in the lab:

A DIY Step-by-Step Guide on How to Anodize Aluminum | SendCutSend .

Is there an advantage of anodizing parts rather than powder coating, and how does it affect bearing tolerances?

link_counts.title: A DIY Step-by-Step Guide on How to Anodize Aluminum | SendCutSend

posts.name: diego
posts.cooked:
Powder coating if done by a non-professional can be unevenly thick so it kind of depends  in all honest. If possible you should plug bearing holes.

Our team will be doing spray-painting possibly next year as we’ve found that it looks pretty when done right and is fairly cheap. Consider that as an option too.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Personally I’d never DIY anodizing.  Sulfuric acid, lye, and lead, all exposed?  Plus figuring out how you safely (and legally!) dispose of the leftovers.  Powder coating or spray painting is much easier and safer to DIY.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
They are not something I would let kids be around, but there are standard procedures for neutralizing bases and acids–it’s why we’re all dragging boxes of baking soda from one end of the country to the other

{aside} Most of you are too young to remember the days before sealed maintenance-free car batteries – you’d have to measure your acid/water level and strength and potentially top it up. {/aside}

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked:
ryan971:

Is there an advantage of anodizing parts rather than powder coating, and how does it affect bearing tolerances?

Anodizing, for FRC purposes, has no impact on weight or tolerances.

That being said, as previously mentioned, the process involves a lot of nasty chemicals and is not something I’d recommend FRC teams do in house.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
And an awful lot of those chemicals are restricted in CA, IIRC.

Rattle-can with proper surface preparation is the way I’d suggest.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
Two other options…both are low weight…both durable.

posts.name: Co-Head Mentor 3658
posts.cooked:
My teams have powdered every robot that I have been part of the for the last 6 season. I have a DIY powder coating station in my garage. Built a powder coating oven out of an old hot dog warmer used in a high school cafeteria. We have not found powder coating very hard but does take some practice and it is relatively cheap. Now all of that said I have always thought hot rods or amazing cars have a great paint job and I believe the same can be said for robots. My last three teams have repeatedly won Quality (2 this season) and Industrial Design awards every year not just because of the powder coating but the judges have mentioned the color of the robot in each of the awards we have won so there is something to be said there for powder coating. Painting aka “rattle-canning” is something I don’t lend myself to leaning too and can be seen as “cheap” is the flaking from that application happens. I would encourage any team to learning the art of powder coating! Awards don’t lie! SJFRC2025.03.07_725 1920×2886 358 KB

SJFRC2025.03.07_725 1920×2886 358 KB

SJFRC2025.03.07_725 1920×2886 358 KB

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Chase Eid
posts.cooked: Maxtube works great with paint. I guess it’s how it’s manufactured it causes small lines on the aluminum that the paint is able to get into, and it stays on there much better then unsanded sheet metal.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
I don’t deny that powder coating is great…it is.  I am just offering options.  Cerakote offer a “cold” series (read as air dry) for teams that don’t have oven options.  The difference is cure time.  They also offer different series for those that have or want oven cured.

I don’t work for them…nor have I used them personally.

EDIT:  Cerakote only needs about a 1 mil (.001 in) coating.  Which is barely anything.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked:
Anodizing is way thinner than Powder Coating. There are many different levels of Anodizing too. Hard Anodize, gives you that surface hardness, but the color option is not as many as regular Anodizing. Powder coat is thick. To powder coat your frame, you probably need to mask the bearing holes.

I won’t DIY anodizing. I would reach out to local plating company and ask for sponsorship. If you are not picky and trying to invent your own color, Black Anodize is pretty common. They can throw your parts when they run it and you might get discounted price or they might even sponsor you.

I would DIY Cerakote/Powder Coat. You need oven big enough for your parts. An elevator tube is too big for junk yard household oven, so there is limit on that too. I like Cerakote. Thin enough and offers so many color options, and pretty durable too. Realize that you do need surface prep equipment to clean and make sure it sticks.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
Cerakote air cure takes hours to be tack-free and around 5 days to cure. Plus it smells like burning urinal cakes and is a severe inhalation risk. I spray Cerakote for both fun and profit, but I would not suggest it for robot parts, even if the test parts I did looked amazing. (Mod note: edited per poster’s request)

Similarly, I would not suggest anodizing aluminum in house. Even after the nasty chemicals you still need to dye and then seal the parts.

You can diy anodized titanium with water, baking soda, and 10-120v at <1A. We did this titanium wire at about 30v to make a nice to blue color.

IMG_20250310_194827536_HDR 1920×2560 383 KB

IMG_20250310_194827536_HDR 1920×2560 383 KB

IMG_20250310_194827536_HDR 1920×2560 383 KB

The rest of our robot is rattle-canned after a modest amount of prep work. Looks amazing on the webcast, but not as great up close in the pits. It’s the right tradeoff of time/money/results for many teams.

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked: You can also use vinyl to “wrap” parts (just like wraps for cars and buses). It is not as durable as some of these solutions, but you can use patterned prints as well as solids. Also depending on lots of factors, some parts can be wrapped after they are on the robot.

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked:
Was there any surface prep on this Air Cure Cerakote? Didn’t even know this exists.

We had to Oxide Blast, which required PPE and certain filtration, and wipe clean before spray, then go into oven.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
It has to be super duper clean bare metal for optimal results.

Degrease

Sandblast or abrade

Propane torch on some parts

Degrease again

You can wait a minute to do steel, but aluminum oxidizes so quickly you really want to spray it asap after removing its natural oxide layer.

It goes on so thin that you also have to be 100% happy with the surface finish. Cerakote hides nothing.

posts.name: JohnD 3322
posts.cooked: Check for a local shop that does anodizing.  There’s a good chance they’ll ‘in-kind’ sponsor you by providing free anodizing.  Don’t expect a quick turn though, so we typically send a few tubes early in the season and then machine after anodize.  it gives a good two-tone finish with shiny holes; and there’s always a Sharpie if you want to get the color back.

posts.name: 829 The Digital Goats Official Curmudgeon.
posts.cooked:
Anodizing does remove a tinny layer of material. The racks that are used for the parts actually get too thin and have to be replaced. Unless you anodize a part many many times though tolerances  wont be affected.

We are lucky to have a anodizing company here in Indy that does parts for many central Indiana teams. Big shout out to Colors Inc.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
IndySam:

Anodizing does remove a tinny layer of material. The racks that are used for the parts actually get too thin and have to be replaced. Unless you anodize a part many many times though tolerances wont be affected.

This is not quite accurate, at least not how it is represented in this post.

Anodizing converts some of the base material to an oxide, the material is not removed and the part gets bigger. If the anodizing is .002in thick then the part grows .001in outwards and has .001in of base material oxidizes (simplistically speaking).

I repair anodizing racks for a local company. The racks (titanium in this case) only break from mechanical damage.*

Anodizing titanium typically changes the dimensions by nanometers to a few microns, which isn’t detectable by most users. Aluminum anodizing can be up to .004-.005in thick (depending on who you ask). Certainly enough to ruin pin and bearing press-fits, and even make some close fit bolt holes too small.

I suspect that you’re conflating etching processes** commonly used to prepare parts for anodizing with anodizing itself. Anodizers may attempt to etch enough material off to match how much the part will grow during anodizing in order to reach final dimensions that match the initial dimensions. Other times the part has been machined under-tolerance and the manufacturer is counting on the oxide layer growth to bring the part back into spec (or closer to the middle of the spec range).

*Racks made of less durable materials that are also used in some types of **etching baths can dissolve over time.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked:
JamesCH95:

but I would suggest it for robot parts, even if the test parts I did looked amazing

Wouldn’t, right

posts.cooked:

Cerakote air cure takes hours to be tack-free and around 5 days to cure. Plus it smells like burning urinal cakes

See, this is why they won’t let you do marketing!

What a great description.

To stay on topic, I’m all in on rattle cans - 90% of the bang with a super low entry point regarding skill and equipment requirements.
